titleInfo.title: Harold Adams and Reynold "Ray" Adams oral history interview

mods.abstract: The brothers discuss their family life, including the ages of their siblings, and the role of Catholicism in their childhood. They discuss the role of neighbors when they were children, and how their Golden Meadow neighborhood has changed. Harold discusses his motivations to attend college. They discuss the oil industry and the growth of wealth on the bayou.
mods.note: This collection includes materials accessioned as Mss. 4700.2103. A digital version of the index (pdf) exists for duplication purposes. A digital version of the audio recording (mp3) exists for duplication purposes and public access in the Special Collections Reading Room. Interview conducted by Melissa Smith.

Harold Adams was born around 1946 in Golden Meadow, La., to Andrew Adams and Letucia Johnfroe Adams. He grew up on Bobs Lane and attended Golden Meadow School and Nicholls State University as a commuter student. He married his wife, Louise Adams, in 1969; they were both teachers. Adams taught at Golden Meadow School, returned to Nicholls to get a master's degree in guidance and psychology, then was asked to be assistant principal of Golden Meadow. A year later he was promoted to principal, a position in which he stayed until he became a supervisor with federal programs, and retired from education after 33 years. Harold and Louise Adams are practicing Catholics, have two children and a number of grandchildren.; Reynold "Ray" Adams, Harold's bother, was born in Golden Meadow, La., around 1944 to Andrew Adams and Letucia Johnfroe Adams. He grew up on Bobs Lane, which was home to the Adams and the Collins extended families. Adams's father was a refrigeration engineer at an ice plant; Adams also worked there for 13 years after high school. In 1976 he became a Golden Meadow deputy police officer, and was eventually promoted to chief of police, a position from which he retired. Adams is a practicing Catholic. He is married to Judy Adams and has children and four grandchildren.
